newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Affco yr profit strong despite hard times.
newsitem.headline: Affco yr profit strong despite hard times.

text.p: AFFCO Holdings Ltd Chairman Peter Jackson said on Thursday the international market place would generate increased returns in the future and continued growth for the New Zealand meat processor.
AFFCO earlier reported an annual operating profit of NZ$26.5 million, 9.5 percent ahead of last year's result and 19.2 percent higher than prospectus forecasts.
The bottom line profit of NZ$31.9 million included a total net gain from non-operating items of NZ$5.47 million.

Over the year to Septebmer, AFFCO bought Mathias International, increased its holding in the New Zealand Lamb Company (North America) and formed a joint venture in South Korea through its 50 percent associate, New Zealand Beef Japan.
Chief Executive Don Manson said trading conditions were difficult during the year.
Revenue was affected by continued low prices for beef and the high New Zealand dollar.
Balancing this were significant improvements in world prices for sheep meats, which were most noticeable in the second half.
Looking ahead, Manson said it was clear that some early forecasts had been too conservative in their estimates of the numbers of livestock to be processed in 1996/7.
"We also believe that there will be significant numbers of cattle carried over from the 1996 season into 1997 in the expectation that beef prices will improve over this time," he said.
Increased processing would improve the prospects for the coming year and prospects in the medium term were positive.

New Zealand had a reputation as a cost-effective producer of red meats. "The fact that we can produce this protein from environmentally friendly, sustainable production systems will be increasingly important to the more affluent markets," he said.
